moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 f6 3. Nxe5: Willing to sacrifice night in order to disrupt King side pawn structure
moves.3... Qe7 4. Nf3 d5 5. d3 dxe4 6. dxe4: I got the feeling that black was playing agressive so I played the next few moves carefully.
moves.6... Qxe4+: Black regains his pawn.  I believe this was a mistake given the black queen's retreat allowed me to develop my knights with Nc3 and then Nd4
moves.7. Be2 Ne7 8. Nc3 Qe6 9. Nd4 Qd7 10. O-O: I am prepared to handle anything black throws at me and then some.
moves.10... Nbc6 11. Be3 Ng6 12. Bh5: Black Kings Knight was dangerous to me, and I felt my light-squared bishop was expendable, so I was willing to keep him pinned for now.  This also relieved pressure on the e5 square.
moves.12... a6 13. Qe2: Starting to take advantage of the e-file.
moves.15... Nd5: The turning point of the game, where black exposes his King to me.
moves.16. Bf4+ Be7 17. Ne4 Ndxf4: Not intending to give up this bishop.  I consider this my first and only blunder. Black would not be able to take advantage as my superior knight development proved later.
moves.18. Qf3 Qc7 19. Ng3: Worried now that black wanted to trade queens.
moves.19... Bd7 20. Ndf5 Bxf5: I beieve Black should have casled on queen side here instead of trading
moves.21. Nxf5: Black might be thinking I would start trading more pieces but I had other plans in mind.
moves.21... Nd5: Black stacking up to defend e7
moves.22. Nxg7+: Look at what spaces the knight has access to this move and next..Black has very few options to defend against this attack.
moves.22... Kf8 23. Ne6+ Kg8 24. Nxc7 Nxc7: Two white knighs for a black bishiop, pawn and queen.  Favorable position for white.
